Award.AwardTitle: NEESR: Interaction of Tsunamis with Short Waves and Bottom Sediment - Numerical and Physical Modeling

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The interaction between short ocean waves and long transient tsunamis is studied in conjunction with sediment transport process. This is in keeping with the theme of the study of tsunami-generated processes in concert with natural oceanographic processes, and will be done from two viewpoints: that of the tsunami's effect on the transported and reworked sediment bed; and that of the effect of the sediment load on the transporting power of the tsunami. Numerical modeling will form the backbone of this work, with physical modeling providing data for process study, parameterization and validation. A sophisticated model based on smoothed particle hydrodynamics will be tightly integrated into the experimental plan. Experiments are planned for the George E. Brown, Jr. Network for Earthquake Engineering Simulation (NEES) Large Wave Flume Facility at Oregon State University during the first two years. The first set of experiments will focus on evaluating the transport power of the tsunami in order to develop the pickup function and other parameterizations for the transport model. The second set of experiments will investigate full bed evolution. In all experiments, forcing will consist of tsunamis and combined tsunami-swell conditions. Measurements will be comprised of: free surface elevations; near-bottom velocities (from acoustic Doppler velocimeters); sediment concentration (from vertical stacks of optical and acoustic backscatter devices); and vertical velocity profiles (via pairs of upward/downward looking pulse-coherent acoustic Doppler profilers). These measurements will also be used to evaluate the dissipation of the tsunami in several different ways. To gage the degree of sediment reworking and redistribution under a tsunami, sediment samples will be analyzed using a digital-optical grain size analyzer. Data from this project will be archived and made available to the public through the NEES Project Warehouse/data repository (http://www.nees.org).

The broader impacts of the proposed work address the present state of knowledge concerning the destructive nature of the tsunami and how effectively it is represented in laboratory studies. It is anticipated that the results of this work will affect present policies governing infrastructural health, emergency procedures and public safety in coastal areas potentially subject to tsunamis. A plan is also outlined concerning work with the NEES Large Wave Flume Facility's education and outreach personnel in aiding their established plans concerning public engagement and education regarding tsunamis and associated hazards, as well as their plans for encouraging careers in science and engineering. This will include live demonstrations of tsunami-sediment interaction in the Large Wave Flume Facility, during which the public will be able to witness the power of an onrushing tsunami. This award is part of the National Earthquake Hazards Reduction Program (NEHRP).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Largely due to their destructive power, tsunamis have generally been studied in isolation from other oceanographic or geological phenomena. Tsunamis are of such a large scale relative to wind waves and swell that no meaningful interaction between the two phenomena seems possible. However, this viewpoint generally assumes that the tsunami remains primarily a long wave phenomenon, with no smaller scale feaures which may interact with the longer swell band waves. Photos of the ocean offshore of Thailand just prior to the 2004 tsunami event revealed small scale, periodic wave structures near the shoreline, close to the length of typical long swell waves. These "fission" waves are generated by the underlying tsunami at landfall, and may affect breaking characteristics and sediment transport properties.

 

This project led to the following outcomes:

 

1) Data analysis techniques designed to study the combined random wave and tsunami wave events were applied to the experimental data. One, a wavelet-based transform, was used to separate the tsunami signal from the combined signal. Comparison with the results of a numerical model revealed that the primary effect of the random swell on the tsunami is in the alteration of the radiation stress gradients, which essentially forced the tsunami to break at a different location than it would have were the random swell not present. The other, a short-time Fourier transform, was applied to the combined tsunami-random wave data, and the resulting spectrograms correlated with an independent estimate of instantaneous dissipation. These showed a correspondence between the occurrence of highly dissipative events and strong energy transfer to high frequencies in the short time Fourier transform spectrograms.

 

2) Part of the testing program involved various combinations of random waves, tsunamis, and periodic cnoidal waves over a sand bed. These waves caused ripples to form on the surface of the sand bed; it was determined that the ripple lengths ranged from 0.4m to 1.2 m over the course of the experiment. This has an impact on the frictional effect the bottom has on tsunamis and other wave forms.

 

3) To test out ideas and hypotheses regarding the nature of the wave forms and their combination, a Korteweg-deVries shallow water wave integrator was developed. This is useful for instances where the data suggest trends but for which no data exists. The integrator helped clear up an issue regarding an older data set which appeared to show that a tsunami would break further offshore (and thus reduce the impact on the shoreline) if random waves were considered along with the tsunami. This interpretation turned out to be incomplete, as the integrator showed that this observation needed to account for phase differences between the tsunami and the random swell. This integrator was also used to investigate the evolution of a meteotsunami in the Gulf of Mexico along the Louisiana shoreline. A lone soliton was determined to be propagating ahead of the meteotsunami; this appeared to have been generated by the interaction of the meteotsunami with nearshore bathymetry.

 

4) The nonlinear characteristics of the combined cnoidal wave – random wave data were investigated using bispectral analysis. This analysis showed that strong coupling between harmonics of the primary wave frequency is seen where the cnoidal wave energy is at least equal to the energy level of the random wave field. Additionally, sharp increases in very low frequency energy were seen in the combined cnoidal  - random wave signals, an indication that the small scale periodic wave forms seen ahead of the landfalling tsunami may affect the level of inundation caused by the tsunami.

 

5) Numerical modeling using 3D models based on Smooth Particle Hydrodynamics (SPH) can provide insight into the mechanisms behind transport of boulders in the nearshore due to tsunamis. The effects of Froude number, submergence factor, and boulder geometry were examined. It was concluded that, not only were these effects quite complex, but that empirical boulder dislodgement parameterizations were quite incomplete in impactful ways. The 3D SPH models are presently also being used to provide improved parameterizations of boulder transport mechanics.

 

6) Outcomes regarding broader impacts involve the upload and ready availability of all data taken during these experiments, and participation in public tour events at the laboratory facility.
